awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Mosquito-borne disease networks and variation in transmission traits across a gradient of anthropogenic impact
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. The spread of zoonotic disease directly ties human and wildlife communities together. Not only are there direct consequences of contracting infection at the individual level, but there are local and global costs of mitigating the effects of disease outbreak. From an ecosystem services perspective, the increase in human-wildlife interactions and subsequent disease emergence caused by deforestation should inform the costs of losing tropical forests. However, there are gaps in knowledge about the impacts of land-use change on vector-borne disease because of the difficulty in collecting such data. This research will use a novel approach of integrating genomic sequencing with vector feeding behavior to quantify patterns of zoonotic disease transmission across a gradient of human activity along the Juruá River in the Amazon rainforest. The research will address the consequences of ongoing landscape transformation on biodiversity and human health; students of diverse backgrounds will be engaged in field-training and research activities throughout the study.

Using novel techniques for sequencing and identifying DNA and RNA present in mosquito vector samples, the Fellow will focus on quantifying (1) the abundance and distribution of host, vector, and pathogen species communities and (2) the transmission traits (biting rate and host choice) of mosquito vectors. To accomplish these objectives, the Fellow will work in collaboration with Brazilian researchers at the Instituto Juruá to collect mosquitoes from forested sites along the Juruá River that span a gradient of anthropogenic activity. The DNA and RNA from these vectors will be sequenced using a molecular method of massive parallel sequencing (metabarcoding). This protocol will allow the Fellow to directly measure the interactions of individual vectors with their hosts (both wildlife and human hosts) as well as quantify disease prevalence across different levels of land-use change. The interdisciplinary nature of the research along with an emphasis on combining field and wet-lab methods present opportunities for mentoring of young scientists and students. The Fellow will use cutting-edge molecular methods which can be generalized to other systems. The study will also promote international collaboration and produce meaningful disease risk data for an initiative to manage wildlife and habitat along the Juruá River.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project was to survey and describe the animal host, mosquito vector, and virus communities along a deforestation gradient in the Brazilian Amazon. The work was focused along the Juruá River, a major tributary of the Amazon River in the western Brazilian Amazon. Forests in this region are largely intact and roadless, restricting most travel to fluvial transportation. Land-use change along the Juruá River spans a gradient of disturbance caused by cattle grazing, small-scale farming, wildlife hunting, and urbanization. This gradient provides a unique opportunity to track how deforestation and increasing urbanization influence disease risk by altering host and vector diversity and their interactions.

This project combined expansive fieldwork and rigorous lab and sequencing methods to achieve the goals that were laid out in the intellectual merits and broader impacts of the project proposal. 

1. Addressing knowledge and data gaps: There is debate concerning whether there is a generalizable effect of land-use change (such as deforestation and/or urbanization) on disease risk. Strong data informing this debate are sparse because of the ecological and sampling complexities that make it challenging to establish direct links between hosts, vectors, and pathogens, especially in remote tropical forests. Our study design aimed at filling in these data gaps by directly measuring these species interactions by sequencing genetic material from mosquito vectors. Because insect vectors take bloodmeals from animal hosts, vectors can theoretically be the source of vector DNA, host DNA (if there is a bloodmeal present), and pathogen DNA or RNA (if the vector or the host are infected with a pathogen). Over the course of this fellowship, our team captured, sorted, and processed over 50,000 female mosquitos collected across urban areas, forests fragmented by farms and ranches, small river communities, and forests with minimal disturbance. Subsequently, we processed all mosquito samples for vector DNA and host DNA and processed a subset of samples for viral RNA. By processing three data streams per sample, we are able to directly tie together vectors with their hosts and with viruses. There are currently three manuscripts in preparation for peer-review that report on our findings. One manuscript directly focuses on the knowledge and data gaps relating to the relationship between deforestation and disease risk. Here, we quantify the changes and patterns of host, vector, and virus community composition and abundance across the gradient of increasing human population density.

2. Advancing molecular methods for ecological research: This project capitalized upon cutting-edge molecular methods and bioinformatics to glean community-level data through environmental DNA methods. Given the instability of RNA (and to a lesser extent DNA), one potential limitation of landscape scale vector collection in remote field conditions has been the feasibility of transporting, separating, and pooling vector samples in the field as well as the post-collection transport to labs for RNA extraction, purification, and library generation. However, with this project we showed that we could isolate high quality RNA and DNA sequencing data from our pooled mosquito samples that rivals other recent RNA and DNA sequencing studies. The success of this workflow from field collection to wet-lab sample processing to DNA and RNA sequencing is the basis of our second manuscript.

3. Broadening participation and building international capacity: At a regional level, this project provides meaningful disease data and genomic resources for an ultra remote region of the Amazon where there is a high prevalence of seasonally circulating zoonotic diseases. We are building phylogenetic trees of the known and unknown viral strains found in our samples, which is the basis of the third manuscript; and the sequence information for any new virus strains will also be added to a genetic database. We have continued our collaboration with the Instituto Jurua in order to disseminate the disease results to the Jurua community when data analysis is completed. Ultimately, our ambition is to build a long-term, high-impact research program in this region dedicated to Amazonian disease ecology. This project has generated foundational data and solidified partnerships with Brazilian institutions to facilitate future research. 

At a global level, understanding the mechanisms that drive disease risk will benefit not only local communities but also other communities in tropical forest systems around the world. This project was an opportunity to expand upon the molecular methods and bioinformatic pipelines so that other research teams can follow similar study designs and analysis workflows, democratizing these fields of study across the globe. The ability to identify, measure, and monitor the important players in zoonotic disease prevalence are vital for collectively working towards disease prevention.
